nodes.text: State-level economic policy uncertainty can be measured using local newspaper text and these measured state-level EPU series matter for understanding drivers and economic effects of policy uncertainty across US states

We construct three monthly state-level EPU indexes per state: EPU-S (state and local sources), EPU-N (national and international sources), and EPU-C (composite capturing both) using nearly 3,500 local newspapers

Newspaper-based EPU measures are feasible and desirable at the state level because newspapers publish frequently, have long digital archives, allow topical decomposition, and multiple papers per state average out idiosyncratic bias

Policy term sets were tailored to separate national from state/local policy mentions, flagging articles containing an economy term, an uncertainty term, and either national or state policy terms; raw indices equal flagged articles over all articles in same newspapers, normalized to 2006-2019 mean
The constructed EPU series are publicly available and updated regularly (policyuncertainty.com/state_epu.html) and a replication package is provided

State and local policy matters are major sources of state-level EPU: before COVID about 50% of EPU-C articles were national-only, 30% state/local-only, 20% both; during March 2020-June 2021 the state/local-only share rose substantially
EPU-S, EPU-N, and EPU-C show large time variation and cross-state heterogeneity; sample covers some states back to 1985 and all states since 2006 with a median 49 papers per state-month

EPU indexes rise around identifiable events: EPU-S around gubernatorial/own-state episodes (e.g., CA electricity crisis 2000-01, Kansas tax changes 2012); EPU-N around presidential elections and national/international episodes (9-11, debt-ceiling 2011, Brexit, government shutdowns, Trump 2016)

Elections increase state-level EPU: close elections (winning margin <4%) have especially large effects; a close presidential election raises EPU-N about 60% and a close gubernatorial election raises EPU-S about 35% controlling for economic conditions and fixed effects

The COVID-19 pandemic produced huge increases in EPU: average EPU-N rose to 2.7 times its pre-COVID peak and average EPU-S rose to over four times its prior peak, and the ratio EPU-S/EPU-N rose substantially across most states after March 2020

Panel VAR analysis (44 states, 2001-2019, six lags, identification via Cholesky ordering) shows that upward own-state EPU-C shocks foreshadow higher unemployment and lower employment with hump-shaped responses peaking about one year after the shock

Spatial spillovers: upward policy uncertainty shocks in contiguous states also negatively affect own-state activity; own-state and border-state EPU shocks of equal size produce similar peak unemployment responses

Magnitude and robustness: peak unemployment response to a unit standard deviation ln(EPU-C) shock is modest (~0.10 percentage point) but estimated precisely; effects are larger in larger states and robust to alternative filters and orderings though somewhat attenuated when EPU is placed last

Pandemic-era cross-state analysis: lockdown stringency (index of shelter-in-place, business closure, restaurant closure, school closure orders) explains cross-state heterogeneity in EPU increases during the pandemic, whereas COVID deaths per capita do not predict higher EPU increases

Pandemic economic outcomes: states with stricter lockdowns experienced larger unemployment increases relative to 2019, and larger increases in state-level EPU during the pandemic are associated with larger unemployment increases conditional on lockdown stringency and deaths; results motivate further causal study
